sections.content: Food ID helps you make informed food choices by providing instant access to detailed product information. Simply scan a product's barcode or enter it manually to see nutritional data, ingredients, allergens, and health scores.

sections.subtitle: Scanning Products
sections.description: Point your camera at any product's barcode. Food ID automatically detects and reads it, then instantly shows you comprehensive product details. If the camera can't read the barcode, tap the keyboard icon to enter it manually.

sections.subtitle: What You'll See
sections.description: Each product shows nutritional values with color-coded icons (green for good, orange for moderate, red for high), key characteristics, allergens, ingredients, and health scores like Nutri-Score, Eco-Score, and NOVA Score. This helps you quickly understand a product's nutritional quality and environmental impact.

sections.subtitle: Product Information Source
sections.description: Food ID uses product information from OpenFoodFacts, a free, open, collaborative database of food products from around the world. The information includes nutritional data, ingredients, allergens, and other product details contributed by a global community of users.

sections.content: Several factors can prevent successful barcode scanning. Here are the most common issues and how to resolve them:

sections.subtitle: Poor Lighting
sections.description: Barcode scanners need adequate light to read codes accurately. Try moving to a brighter area or turning on additional lights. Avoid direct sunlight or harsh reflections that can wash out the barcode.

sections.subtitle: Distance and Angle
sections.description: Hold your device at a comfortable distance (about 6-12 inches) from the barcode. Keep the camera parallel to the barcode surface. Angled or tilted barcodes are harder to read.

sections.subtitle: Damaged or Dirty Barcodes
sections.description: Scratched, torn, or dirty barcodes may not scan properly. Try cleaning the barcode surface or use manual entry if the code is unreadable.

sections.subtitle: Product Not in Database
sections.description: If the barcode scans successfully but no product information appears, the product may not be in the OpenFoodFacts database yet. You can add it by visiting openfoodfacts.org and contributing the product information.

sections.subtitle: Camera Permission
sections.description: Make sure you've granted camera permission to Food ID. If scanning doesn't work, check your device settings and ensure camera access is enabled for the app.

question: How are nutrients evaluated and colored?
title: Nutrient Evaluation

sections.content: Food ID uses two methods to determine nutrient levels and color coding:

sections.subtitle: Primary Method: Official Product Information
sections.description: When available, Food ID uses official nutrition information directly from Open Food Facts. This is the most reliable source as it's based on the product's actual nutrition label.

sections.subtitle: Fallback Method: Industry Standards
sections.description: If official nutrition information is not available, Food ID determines nutrient levels using industry-standard guidelines based on EU nutrition labeling regulations and health recommendations from WHO and EFSA.

sections.subtitle: Color Coding
sections.description: Standard nutrients (fat, sugar, salt, calories): Low = Green (good), Moderate = Orange (caution), High = Red (limit). Positive nutrients (protein, fiber): High = Green (good), Low/Moderate = Gray (neutral). Insufficient data = Gray.

sections.subtitle: Missing Information
sections.description: If a nutrient value is not available or cannot be determined, the icon remains gray to indicate that this information is not available for the product.

question: How do I add products to favorites?
title: Favorites
answer: When viewing a product's details, tap the heart icon at the bottom of the screen. The heart will turn red, indicating the product has been added to your favorites. Access your favorites anytime from the favorites tab.

question: Where is my scan history stored?
title: Data Storage

sections.content: All your scanned products and favorites are stored locally on your device. This means your data never leaves your phone and remains completely private.

sections.subtitle: Local Storage
sections.description: Your scan history, favorites, and product information are stored only on your device. Nothing is sent to external services or stored online.

sections.subtitle: Privacy
sections.description: Since everything stays on your device, you have complete control. If you uninstall the app, all your information is removed. Product details are retrieved from OpenFoodFacts when you scan, but your personal scan history and favorites never leave your device.

question: How are positive and negative assessments generated?
title: Assessments

sections.content: Food ID analyzes the product's nutritional content including calories, proteins, fats, carbohydrates, fiber, sodium, and sugars. We compare these values against recommended daily intake guidelines based on EU regulations and industry standards.

sections.subtitle: Positive Assessments
sections.description: Products receive positive assessments when they are high in beneficial nutrients (fiber, protein) and low in components to limit (saturated fats, sodium, sugars). These products support a balanced diet and healthy eating habits.

sections.subtitle: Negative Assessments
sections.description: Products receive negative assessments when they contain high levels of saturated fats, sodium, or sugars. These should be consumed in moderation as part of a balanced diet.

question: Why can't I find some products?
title: Missing Products

sections.content: Not all products are available in OpenFoodFacts yet. The information is community-driven and constantly growing, with millions of products already available.

sections.subtitle: Why Products Might Be Missing
sections.description: New products, regional items, or less common brands may not yet be available. The information relies on community contributions to expand coverage.

sections.subtitle: How to Add Products
sections.description: You can contribute by adding missing products to OpenFoodFacts. Visit openfoodfacts.org to scan the barcode and add product information including nutrition facts, ingredients, and photos.

sections.content: Nutri-Score is an official food labeling system, developed in France and adopted by many European countries. It serves as a simple, graphic indicator that helps consumers quickly assess a product's overall nutritional quality.

sections.subtitle: The best score
sections.description: Awarded to products with the highest nutritional quality, minimal calories, fats, sugars, and salt, rich in fiber and/or protein. Examples: fresh fruits, vegetables, wholegrain products, and olive oil.

sections.subtitle: Very good nutritional quality
sections.description: Products are a good choice for daily consumption, with a very good nutrient balance, though they may contain slightly more fat or sugar than category A. Examples: unsweetened low-fat yogurts and certain types of wholegrain bread.

sections.subtitle: Average or "neutral" score
sections.description: Products can be included in the diet but should be alternated with A and B products. They have moderate negative components, or their positive characteristics don't fully offset fats or salt. Examples: most types of cheese or white bread.

sections.subtitle: Low nutritional quality
sections.description: Such products have a high content of negative components and should be consumed in limited quantities. Examples: many sweetened breakfast cereals or processed meat products.

sections.subtitle: The worst score
sections.description: Assigned to products with very low nutritional quality, characterized by very high content of calories, fats, sugar, or salt. Consumption of such products, like chips, chocolate spreads, or sugary soft drinks, should be minimized.

sections.content: The Eco-Score is a comprehensive environmental label that assesses the ecological impact of food products throughout their entire lifecycle. It was designed to provide consumers with transparent information on how the product affects the planet, using a simple, graphical five-color, five-letter scale.

sections.subtitle: Best Environmental Choice
sections.description: Indicates a minimal environmental impact. Products typically score high on LCA due to low CO2 emissions (e.g., plant-based foods) and earn maximum bonuses for being organic, locally sourced, and packaged in fully recyclable or reusable materials. Example: seasonal, organic, minimally packaged vegetables.

sections.subtitle: Good Environmental Choice
sections.description: Represents a good overall environmental profile. Products are generally sustainable but may have a slightly higher impact in one area, such as packaging or transport. They often include plant-based items or sustainably farmed goods that use recyclable materials.

sections.subtitle: Moderate Environmental Impact
sections.description: This is the average or "neutral" score. Products often represent the standard for a category, with a measurable environmental impact, potentially due to energy-intensive processing, some non-recyclable packaging components, or longer supply chains. They require a balanced approach to consumption.

sections.subtitle: Moderate Environmental Impact
sections.description: Products have a measurable environmental impact, potentially due to energy-intensive processing, some non-recyclable packaging components, or longer supply chains. They require a balanced approach to consumption.

sections.subtitle: Highest Environmental Impact
sections.description: This is the worst score, signifying a very high environmental impact. Products usually combine a high LCA score (e.g., beef) with multiple penalties, such as a lack of origin traceability and problematic, disposable packaging. Consumption of these products should be minimized.

sections.content: The NOVA Classification is a system developed by Brazilian scientists that categorizes food products exclusively according to the extent of their industrial processing. Unlike Nutri-Score, NOVA does not assess nutrient content like sugar, fat, or salt; instead, it focuses on production methods and ingredients.

sections.subtitle: Unprocessed or Minimally Processed Foods
sections.description: These products are either naturally occurring or slightly altered to preserve them, make them safer, or improve palatability. Permitted alterations include simple techniques like washing, peeling, pasteurization, freezing, or milling. These foods retain their essential identity and nutrient profile. Examples: fresh, dried, or frozen fruits and vegetables, whole milk, fresh meat, eggs, and basic cereals like rice.

sections.subtitle: Processed Culinary Ingredients
sections.description: This group comprises substances extracted directly from Group 1 foods or obtained from nature, used primarily in the kitchen for preparing, seasoning, or preserving other foods. They are not meant to be consumed on their own. They are extracted through processes such as pressing, refining, or drying. Common examples: vegetable oils, salt, sugar, honey, and butter.

sections.subtitle: Processed Foods
sections.description: Processed foods are relatively simple items made by combining foods from Group 1 with culinary ingredients from Group 2 (salt, oil, or sugar). The goal is to extend shelf life or enhance sensory characteristics. These products typically contain only a few ingredients and are still easily recognizable as modifications of whole foods. Examples: simple cheese (fermented milk with salt), canned vegetables in brine, bread made with minimal ingredients, and plain yogurts.

sections.subtitle: Ultra-Processed Foods (UPF)
sections.description: These products represent the highest degree of industrial processing. They are often formulated from ingredients derived primarily from industrial processes and include numerous additives not typically used in home cooking. NOVA 4 foods often contain substances like colorants, emulsifiers (such as E407), flavor enhancers, hydrogenated oils, hydrolyzed proteins, and modified starch. These items are engineered for maximum convenience, palatability, and long shelf life. Their consumption should be strictly limited. Examples: most ready-to-eat frozen meals, sugary soft drinks, mass-produced breakfast cereals, most processed meats like sausages, and various packaged snacks and chips.
